Scientists have discovered that Volatile Organic Compounds (<math alttext="V O Cs"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>VOCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) emitted from trees can contribute to photochemical smog formation. Data in the table above were collected in 2006 and 2014 in Berlin, Germany. Isoprene is a <math alttext="V O C"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>VOC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> released by some tree species. Impact factor refers to the percentage of ozone attributed to the isoprene.
content.question: Which of the following claims is best supported by the data shown in the table?

choices.label: Ozone levels are not a serious air quality concern in Berlin.
Ozone levels in Berlin were consistently higher in 2014 than in 2006.
Isoprene’s contribution to ozone levels in Berlin was greatest in July of both years.
Isoprene levels were negatively correlated with maximum temperature.

content.answer: Isoprene’s contribution to ozone levels in Berlin was greatest in July of both years.

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Describe relationships among variables in data represented.
